{{also|Sitzen}} ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|sitzen}}, from {{inh|de|goh|sizzen}}, originally {{m|goh||*sitten}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*sitjaną}}, from {{inh|de|ine-pro|*sed-}}. Cognate with {{cog|nds|sitten}}, {{cog|nl|zitten}}, {{cog|en|sit}}, {{cog|da|sidde}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈzɪtsn̩/|/ˈzɪtsən/}} * {{audio|de|De-sitzen.ogg|audio}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-strong|class=5|sitzt|saß|gesessen|past subjunctive=säße|auxiliary=both}} # {{lb|de|intransitive}} to [[sit]]; to [[perch]] # {{lb|de|intransitive}} to [[stay]] (in one place); to [[remain]]; to [[be]] (in a particular place or state) #: {{uxi|de|Wir '''saßen''' fest!|We were stuck!}} # {{lb|de|intransitive|of clothing}} to [[fit]] # {{lb|de|intransitive|in certain constructions|e.g. with ''{{l|de|voller}}''}} to [[be]] #: {{uxi|de|Der Schrank '''sitzt''' voller Motten.|The cupboard '''is''' full of moths.}} # {{lb|de|intransitive|colloquial}} to [[do time]]; to [[spend]] time in jail # {{lb|de|intransitive|colloquial|of a strike, a comment, etc.}} to [[hit home]]; to have a significant effect # {{lb|de|intransitive|Swiss}} to [[sit down]] ====Usage notes==== The most frequent auxiliary with ''sitzen'' is {{m|de|haben}}: ''Ich habe gesessen.'' In northern and central Germany, only this form is used. In southern Germany, Austria, and Switzerland, {{m|de|sein}} is common in the vernacular and also, alternatively, in standard usage: ''Ich bin gesessen.'' ====Conjugation==== {{de-conj-strong|sitz|saß|gesessen|hs|||säß|a|a|||a}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|sitzenbleiben}} * {{l|de|sitzenlassen}} * {{l|de|Sitzgelegenheit}} * {{l|de|Sitzfleisch}} * {{l|de|Sitzkrieg|g=m}} * {{l|de|Sitzplatz}} * {{l|de|Sitzriese}} * {{l|de|Sitzzwerg}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|de|Sitz}} * {{l|de|Sitzung}} * {{l|de|besitzen}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}}
